title: 112_s3531
content: Expansion of credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property. Expansion of credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property includes increasing the credit percentage to 50% for hydrogen-related property and removing the dollar limitation for such property. Additionally, the credit is allowable for refueling property for certain motor vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads. The credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property is expanded to include property for storing or dispensing at least 85% hydrogen. The credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property is expanded to include specified off-highway vehicles for storing or dispensing at least 85% hydrogen. The term 'specified off-highway vehicles' includes all motor-propelled vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads, regardless of registration for highway use. The term 'specified off-highway vehicles' includes motor-propelled vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads, excluding certain equipment like farm tractors and bulldozers that do not carry loads. The term 'specified off-highway vehicles' excludes farm tractors, bulldozers, and similar equipment that do not carry loads. The credit for hydrogen property is extended through December 31, 2016. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the effective date. The amendments to section 30C(g) of the Code extend the credit for hydrogen property through December 31, 2016. The effective date for these amendments varies depending on the type of property and the enactment date of the Act. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells, with a 50 percent increase for qualified fuel cell property used in a combined heat and power system with an energy efficiency percentage of 70 percent or more. The text chunk discusses the increased investment credit for fuel cell property used in a combined heat and power system with an energy efficiency percentage of 70 percent or more. The text chunk amends the definition of energy efficiency percentage to be at least 60% but less than 70%. It also includes conforming amendments to the tax code related to this definition. The text chunk modifies clauses in the tax code related to qualified fuel cell property credits. The tax code limits the credit for fuel cell property placed in service based on capacity: $2,500 for each 0.5 kilowatt for one type of property, $2,000 for another type, and a different amount for a third type. The tax code limits the credit for fuel cell property placed in service based on capacity: $2,500 for one type of property, $2,000 for another type, and $1,500 for a third type. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
